See All#

All With Options#

Module to show content from the db, using note files.

notes.all.all(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

When called without options, collects and shows the db’s content.

Options:

-n

Integer defining how many of the more recent entries will be displayed. For example: ntall -n 5, returns the five latest entries in the database.

Called with ntall.

Delete#

Command line version of Notes’ delete function.

notes.delete.delete(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

Function that deletes one, several or range of entries in the ‘notes’ database.

You can call it with ntdlt in the following forms:

  1. Delete non sequential entries. Surround the ids with quotation marks and separate them with a comma:

    ntdlt '435,436'

  2. Delete sequential entries. Envelop first and last ids with quotation marks and separate them with a dash:

    ntdlt '437-439'

  3. Delete single entry:

    ntdlt 66

Search#

Module to do searches in db, but present the notes from files.

notes.search.search(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

Receives search query, looks in db, and outputs to terminal with Blessed.

Called with ntsrch.

Update#

Command line implementation of the update funtion on Notes.

notes.update.update(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

Updates the value of some column in a given id.

Options:

-n

Integer of the ntid value.

-c

Column to update.

-u

String with the update. If you chosen ‘note’ in ‘column’, it’ll open a Vim page for you to edit it.

Called with ntupdt.

Add#

Command line version of the ‘add’ function in Notes. Here, debloated and adapted to work with file notes.

notes.add.add.add(*args: Any, **kwargs: Any) → Any#

Gets information through command line, sends it to the db.

Options:

-t

Enter the title string for the note.

-k

Accepts three keyword values as individual strings.

-n

Opens Vim so as to write a note.

Called with ntadd.

All No Options#

Coloring each entry with Pygmentyze was taking a long time. This version is quicker. Pygmentyze will still be visible on the other commands.

notes.nall.nall()[source]#

Collects and shows the db’s content.

Called with nall.
